app package¶

Each application written in Django consists of a Python package that follows a certain convention and Django comes with a utility that automatically generates the basic directory structure of an app.
(Django docs: https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/3.2/intro/tutorial01/)
In the followings we will overview our application's structure.

Subpackages¶

  • app.migrations package
    • Submodules
    • app.migrations.0001_initial module
    • app.migrations.0002_product_image_name module
    • Module contents

Submodules¶

app.admin module¶

This module is expected to register models with the admin, because part of Django is the automatic admin interface. It reads metadata from the models to provide a quick, model-centric interface where trusted users can manage content on the site.
For more details: https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/3.2/ref/contrib/admin/)

app.apps module¶

Django contains a registry of installed applications that stores configuration and provides introspection. It also maintains a list of available models. (Django docs: https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/3.2/ref/applications/)

app.forms module¶

app.models module¶

We use this to create our backend models for the project. It contains the declaration and definition of "Profile", "Product" and "Product with quantity". These are the definitive sources of information about our data.
(Django docs: https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/3.2/topics/db/models/)

app.tests module¶

We used the test module obviously to test our work. We made test cases to check if the pages load correctly, and for checking that the functionalities in the background are working. To run the tests we should be in the same directory as the "manage.py", and we should type the following command: python manage.py test app
(Django docs: https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/3.2/topics/testing/overview/)

app.urls module¶

The `urlpatterns` list routes URLs to views. (For more details: https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/3.2/topics/http/urls/)

app.views module¶

In views.py we place view functions, which are Python functions which take a Web request and return a Web response. This response can be the HTML contents of a Web page, or a redirect, or a 404 error, or an XML document, or an image . . . or anything. In our case we use this for getting the HTML contents of the following pages: home, cart, search, searchresults, register, login. In addition we use it for getting the expected responses for "add to cart", "remove from cart", "login", "register", "search" functionalities.
(Django docs: https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/3.2/topics/http/views/
